title: Hungary Blocks EU Loan to Ukraine Over Oil Dispute
summary: Hungary's foreign minister says his country will stop a big loan from the European Union to Ukraine. The loan is worth 90 billion euros and was meant to help Ukraine with its military and economy. Hungary is doing this because it wants Russian oil to flow again through a pipeline called Druzhba. The oil shipments stopped after a drone attack damaged the pipeline in Ukraine. Hungary and Slovakia, two countries in Europe, rely on this Russian oil and have accused Ukraine of not fixing the problem on purpose. They stopped sending diesel fuel to Ukraine this week. Hungary's leader, Viktor Orbán, often supports Russia and has argued that his country needs Russian energy to keep its economy strong. Many other European countries have reduced or stopped using Russian energy since the war started, but Hungary and Slovakia still use it. This decision comes just before the fourth anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

background_read: The European Union (EU) is a group of countries in Europe that work together on things like trade and laws. Ukraine is a country in Europe that is at war with Russia. Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, and many countries have tried to help Ukraine by giving money or stopping trade with Russia. Hungary is a member of the EU but often disagrees with other countries about Russia. Oil is a natural resource used for energy, and pipelines help transport it across countries. This article talks about how Hungary is using its power in the EU to block help for Ukraine until it gets Russian oil again.
Article_Structure: WHO: Hungary's foreign minister Péter Szijjártó and Prime Minister Viktor Orbán
WHAT: Hungary will block a 90-billion-euro EU loan to Ukraine until Russian oil shipments resume through the Druzhba pipeline
WHERE: Hungary, Ukraine, and the European Union
WHY: Because Hungary accuses Ukraine of deliberately holding up oil supplies and wants to pressure Ukraine to restart them, as Hungary relies on Russian energy for its economy

perspectives.description: Hungary believes Ukraine is blackmailing it by not fixing the pipeline and that blocking the loan is a fair response to protect its energy needs.
